urn:contentItem:600V-R9W1-JBCN-44VN-00000-00Trump threatens to regulate or close social media after Twitter fact-checks him2020-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisNEWSTrump threatens to regulate or close social media after Twitter fact-checks him

WASHINGTON D.C. — President Donald Trump on Wednesday threatened social media companies with new regulation or even shuttering a day after Twitter added fact checks to two of his tweets.

The president can't unilaterally regulate or close the companies, which would require action by Congress or the Federal Communications Commission. But that didn't stop Trump from issuing a strong warning.

Claiming tech giants "silence conservative voices," Trump tweeted, "We will strongly regulate, or close them down, before we can ever allow this to happen."

Twitter fact checked Trump for the first time on Tuesday when he called mail-in ballots "fraudulent" and predicted that "mail boxes will be robbed," among other things. Under the tweets, there is now a link reading "Get the facts about mail-in ballots" that guides users to a Twitter "moments" page with fact checks and news stories about Trump's unsubstantiated claims.

Trump replied on Twitter, accusing the platform of "interfering in the 2020 Presidential Election" and insisted that, "as president, I will not allow this to happen." His 2020 campaign manager, Brad Parscale, said Twitter's "clear political bias" had led the campaign to pull "all our advertising from Twitter months ago." Twitter banned all political advertising last November.

Trump did not explain his threat Wednesday. The call to expand regulation appeared to fly in the face of long-held conservative principles on deregulation.

But some Trump allies, who have alleged bias on the part of tech companies, have questioned whether platforms like Twitter and Facebook should continue to enjoy liability protections as "platforms" under federal law — or be treated more like publishers, which could face lawsuits over content.

The protections have been credited with allowing the unfettered growth of the internet for more than two decades, but now, some Trump allies are advocating that social media companies face more scrutiny.

"Big tech gets a huge handout from the federal government," Republican Sen. Josh Hawley told Fox News. "They get this special immunity, this special immunity from suits and from liability that's worth billions of dollars to them every year. Why are they getting subsidized by federal taxpayers to censor conservatives, to censor people critical of China?"

urn:contentItem:5WF1-WFR1-JCMN-Y4SF-00000-00Trump threatens to sue Facebook and Google and rails against big tech companies for being 'totally biased'2019-06-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump threatens to sue Facebook and Google and rails against big tech companies for being 'totally biased'Ben Gilbert

Jun 26, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Reuters President Donald Trump[1] threatened Google[2] and Facebook[3] with potential lawsuits, and claimed Silicon Valley's tech giants are biased against Republicans, in an interview with Fox Business on Wednesday morning[4]. "We should be suing Google and Facebook, which, perhaps we will," he said. Trump also claimed that tech companies are "trying to rig" the 2020 US presidential election. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[5] President Donald Trump threatened to sue Google and Facebook on Wednesday morning during an interview with Fox Business News[6]. "We should be suing Google and Facebook and all that," he said.

"Which, perhaps we will." Trump didn't specify why he believes the government should be suing Google and Facebook, but mentioned it in the context of fines the European Union has levied against companies like Apple and Google in recent months. Most recently, the EU fined Google $1.7 billion[7] for its third breach of EU antitrust rules in three years. Trump claimed that Google specifically is attempting to "rig" the 2020 US presidential election, calling Google "totally biased." He cited a congressional hearing on Tuesday[8] where Senator Ted Cruz asked Google user experience director Maggie Stanphill about political bias at Google. Additionally, Trump said that Twitter is stopping people from following his Twitter account. "I will tell you, they make it very hard for people to join me on Twitter, and they make it very much harder for me to get out the message. It's incredible," he said, without citing evidence to support his claims. Trump suggested he would pick up "five times more followers" if he were a Democrat. This isn't the first time Trump has suggested that Twitter is stopping him from gaining new followers[9]. In the past, he's accused Twitter of "constantly taking people off list" and making it "hard for people to sign on," apparently suggesting the company removes followers from his Twitter account and makes it hard for people to follow him. You can check out the full clip from Fox Business right here[10].NOW WATCH: Facebook's scandals weren't enough for people to stop using it. Here's how the company has held up through data hacks, lawsuits, and massive security threats.[11]See Also: Amazon, unlike Google and Facebook, is punching back at 2020 Democrats[12]This forgotten investigation into Microsoft, 10 years before the antitrust trial, let it get away with tactics that sealed its tech dominance, according to a key player[13]'They are going to get steamrolled': California's governor warns Facebook, YouTube, and other social media giants that government regulation is coming[14] SEE ALSO:US tech firms are reportedly working around the Huawei ban, and Trump Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:600P-58H1-JCMN-Y4WG-00000-00Trump Threatens Twitter After Presidential Tweets Get Fact Checked2020-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump Threatens Twitter After Presidential Tweets Get Fact CheckedKyna Doles

May 27, 2020( The Huffington Post: https://www.huffpost.com/ Delivered by Newstex) WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump on Wednesday threatened social media companies with new regulation or even shuttering a day after Twitter added fact checks to two of his tweets.The president can't unilaterally regulate or close the companies, which would require action by Congress or the Federal Communications Commission. But that didn't stop Trump from angrily issuing a strong warning.Claiming tech giants 'silence conservative voices,' Trump tweeted, 'We will strongly regulate, or close them down, before we can ever allow this to happen.'Republicans feel that Social Media Platforms totally silence conservatives voices. We will strongly regulate, or close them down, before we can ever allow this to happen.

We saw what they attempted to do, and failed, in 2016. We can't let a more sophisticated version of that.... — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 27, 2020[1] ....happen again. Just like we can't let large scale Mail-In Ballots take root in our Country. It would be a free for all on cheating, forgery and the theft of Ballots. Whoever cheated the most would win. Likewise, Social Media. Clean up your act, NOW!!!! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 27, 2020[2] And he repeated his unsubstantiated claim — which sparked his latest showdown with Silicon Valley — that expanding mail-in voting 'would be a free for all on cheating, forgery and the theft of Ballots.'Trump and his campaign angrily lashed out Tuesday afterTwitter added a warning phrase to two Trump tweets[3]that called mail-in ballots 'fraudulent' and predicted that 'mail boxes will be robbed,' among other things. Under the tweets, there is now a link reading 'Get the facts about mail-in ballots' that guides users to a Twitter 'moments' page with fact checks and news stories about Trump's unsubstantiated claims.Trump replied on Twitter, accusing the platform of 'interfering in the 2020 Presidential Election' and insisting that 'as president, I will not allow this to happen.' His 2020 campaign manager, Brad Parscale, said Twitter's 'clear political bias' had led the campaign to pull 'all our advertising from Twitter months ago.' Twitter has banned all political advertising since last November.Trump did not explain his threat Wednesday, and the call to expand regulation appeared to fly in the face of long-held conservative principles on deregulation.But some Trump allies, who have alleged bias on the part of tech companies, have questioned whether platforms like Twitter and Facebook should continue to enjoy liability protections as 'platforms' under federal law — or be treated more like publishers, which could face lawsuits over content.The protections have been credited with allowing the unfettered growth of the internet for more than two decades, but now some Trump allies are advocating that social media companies face more scrutiny.'Big tech gets a huge handout from the federal government,' Republican Sen. Josh Hawley told Fox News. 'They get this special immunity, this special immunity from suits and from liability that's worth billions of dollars to them every year. Why are they getting subsidized by federal taxpayers to censor conservatives, to censor people critical of China.' This article originally appeared on The Huffington Post https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-threatens-twitter-after-presidential-tweets-get-fact-checked_n_5ece67cec5b691b74ddc3481?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000603; [ 1]:   https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1265601611310739456?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 2]:   https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1265601615261827072?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 3]:   https://apnews.com/700c52aab0869253625b80255a397f19

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60K9-W5H1-F03R-N0YG-00000-00Trump To Block Big Tech's Challenge To Social Media Executive Order2020-08-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump To Block Big Tech's Challenge To Social Media Executive OrderDavid Challis

Aug 13, 2020( Android Headlines: http://androidheadlines.com Delivered by Newstex) The Trump administration has filed a motion asking a court to dismiss big tech's challenge to his social media executive order. As reported by Reuters[1], Trump has described the situation as a "profound misunderstanding". Trump first filed the executive order against "social media bias" after his tweets were labelled for fact-checking. Then a group of senators and the FCC tried to redefine the regulation[2] of social media organizations.

This also comes as Trump is embroiled in a war against the Chinese owners of TikTok[3]. Trump's order will channel complaints about political bias to the Federal Trade Commission. The U.S. Commerce Department has also petitioned the FCC for new laws to gain transparency on how social media companies moderate content. This has all prompted the Center for Democracy and Technology (CDT) to file a lawsuit against Trump's directives. CDT's lawsuit argued that the executive order violates the First Amendment rights of the companies concerned. Now Trump has moved to strike this suit down.Trump attempts to strike down big tech's lawsuitCDT argues that the executive order reduces the ability of Americans to speak freely online. However, the administration argues that the order only affects government agencies and not private companies. The motion filed by the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia tries to clarify this. It states, "The EO challenged here imposes no obligations on any private party" The motion goes onto to note that it could lead officials to examine, "allegations that large social media online platforms have displayed political bias in moderating content".Trump makes the latest move in tensions between big tech and WashingtonThe lawsuit and ensuing back and forth statements are a good reflection of the relationship between big tech and Washington. Tensions have risen over Trump's administration as he has tried to use social media companies as tools in his arsenal. Avery Gardiner, CDT's general counsel, also called the executive order "unconstitutional". Gardiner has also said that the administration is "resorting to legal manoeuvring". Instead of "actually trying to address the merits of the issues". White House spokesman Judd Deere said the administration moved to dismiss the case because "it is not a valid legal argument". Deer went onto say "doesn't understand how administrative action works". Even questioning their understanding of the legal system. The Department of Justice is yet to comment on the issue. Whilst Twitter called the move a "reactionary and politicized approach to a landmark law." Tensions between social media companies and the Trump administration are unlikely to go away any time soon. This is just the latest chapter in that particular story and what happens over the next few months will no doubt be fascinating. The post Trump To Block Big Tech's Challenge To Social Media Executive Order[4] appeared first on Android Headlines[5]. [ 1]: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-socialmedia-exclusive/exclusive-trump-administration-asks-court-to-dismiss-big-techs-challenge-to-social-media-executive-order-idUSKCN25831P [ 2]: https://www.androidheadlines.com/2020/06/senators-want-the-fcc-to-redefine-section-230-regulate-social-networks.html [ 3]: https://www.androidheadlines.com/2020/08/tiktok-shocked-trump-executive-order-lawsuit-possible.html [ 4]: https://www.androidheadlines.com/2020/08/trump-to-block-big-techs-challenge-to-social-media-executive-order.html [ 5]: https://www.androidheadlines.com

The Trump administration has filed a motion asking a court to dismiss big tech's challenge to his social media executive order. As reported by Reuters , Trump has described the situation as a "profound misunderstanding". Trump first filed the executive order against "social media bias" after his tweets were labelled for fact-checking. Then a group of senators and the FCC tried to redefine the regulation of social media organizations. This also comes as Trump is embroiled in a war against the Chinese owners of TikTok . Trump's order will channel complaints about political bias to the Federal Trade Commission. The U.S. Commerce Department has also petitioned the FCC for new laws to gain transparency on how social media companies moderate content. Tensions have risen over Trump's administration as he has tried to use social media companies as tools in his arsenal. Avery Gardiner, CDT’s general counsel, also called the executive order "unconstitutional". Gardiner has also said that the administration is "resorting to legal manoeuvring". Deer went onto say "doesn’t understand how administrative action works". Even questioning their understanding of the legal system. The Department of Justice is yet to comment on the issue. Whilst Twitter called the move a "reactionary and politicized approach to a landmark law." Tensions between social media companies and the Trump administration are unlikely to go away any time soon. This is just the latest chapter in that particular story and what happens over the next few months will no doubt be fascinating. Advertisement

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R7G-FH81-DY0W-40RP-00000-00Trump To Hold Tax Reform Ceremony At White House; Tax Loopholes Debate; Stocks Fell After Tax Vote; Gary Cohn Blames Congress For Carried2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump To Hold Tax Reform Ceremony At White House; Tax Loopholes Debate; Stocks Fell After Tax Vote; Gary Cohn Blames Congress For CarriedLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX ANCHOR: -- hopping into a bus. They make their way to the White House and Ashley Webster will monitor what they say when they do. Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: -- the party bus. Neil, thank you very much.

Breaking right now, President Trump will be speaking in about an hour from now, after securing his first legislative win, tax reform, finally, Republican lawmakers passing the most consequential reform in over 30 years in a generation.

Good afternoon everybody. I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. Welcome everyone to "The Intelligence Report."

And by the way, as Neil said, you are looking live right now of Republican House members getting on buses, (INAUDIBLE) those bus. They're going to head on over to the White House to celebrate this big win with the President and they're getting driven over there in those buses.

Now, which the President, by the way, did with no Democratic support and without losing a single Republican senator, so, will we see more legislative wins next year in 2018? And what's next for the Republican Party? We'll be asking Presidential Historian Doug Wead and Republican Congressman Doug Collins. We'll get their thoughts on that.

Plus, we've got the latest on the topic of Trish, has been very passionate about, the carried interest loophole. Trump Chief Economic Advisor, Gary Cohn saying today, if it were up to him and the President this loophole would have been closed. The question begs, why wasn't it? We've got the Intel on that.

But first to Blake Burman at the White House where in a short time from now the President will be taking a big victory lap. Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Ashley, and those buses will be pulling into the White House here shortly for that victory lap, 3:00 this afternoon here at the White House. The President will be sidelined or, will have alongside him rather Senate and House Republicans who delivered this tax bill across the finish line.

We got a little bit of a preview from the President earlier today as he was joined by his cabinet about just exactly what he might say.

Earlier today he called this massive tax cuts and reform on the individual side. He touted a doubling of the child tax credit, doubling of the standard deduction relief from the death tax. And on the corporate side, he talked about how the corporate rate was dropped down to 21 percent, nearly half, and how money will be repatriated from back overseas.

However, there was also a new talking point from the President as well and that is he says now with the repeal of the Obamacare individual mandate, which this -- is included in this tax bill, he said essentially it is a repeal of Obamacare. And the President said that he instructed others or at least there was implicit instruction not to bring up the Obamacare repeal until now. Listen here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: So in this bill, not only do we have massive tax cuts and tax reform, we have essentially repealed Obamacare.

I told people specifically, be quiet with the fake news media because I don't want them talking too much about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: There was also another big admission from the administration today, and that came in the form of Gary Cohn. In an interview here in Washington with Axios, Cohn said the one thing that he could change, that this administration could change should they have been given the opportunity to do so, would be to get rid of the carried interest loophole but Cohn contended it was not possible because of the pushback on Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GARY COHN, TRUMP'S CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISOR: We would have cut carried interest. We've been trying to cut carried interest, man, we probably tried 25 times.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Here at the White House 3:00, we will get the ceremony. Important to note, it is not a signing ceremony. That will not happen today. This is merely just a celebratory victory lap. We are told that it could take until Tuesday of next week for the President to actually receive this bill and until, because of how big this is and the government processes that have to take place. So it is still undetermined at this point exactly when the President might sign it and exactly where. Ashley.

WEBSTER: The party is beginning nevertheless.

BURMAN: Yes.

WEBSTER: Blake Burman, thank you very much at the White House.

"The Wall Street Journal" editorial board which has been critical of the President praising the Republican tax bill saying, "it is the most pro- growth policy since the Reagan reforms of 1991 and 1986," but the board did note that Reagan reforms were better for individuals.

Joining me now with their thoughts, Moody's Chief Economist, John Lonski, and Hoover Institute Research Fellow, Lanhee Chen.

Lanhee, I just want to get you first. I was looking at some of your notes on this. You are we'll see faster growth, better job creation, 80 percent of taxpayers will see tax cuts because of this bill, including many middle income Americans. So in your mind this is a huge plus for the economy?

LANHEE CHEN, HOOVER INSTITUTE RESEARCH FELLOW: I do think it's a huge plus for the economy. I think that it's unfortunate it hasn't been covered more that way. If you look at the impacts on individuals, you've got significant tax relief for many individuals, particularly the middle class. I do think the corporate rate tax cut is hugely important. Immediate expensing is going to move up, a lot of that capital expenditure into 2018 and 2019.

So I think this is a very, very big deal. It's a huge accomplishment. And we haven't seen nearly the kind of coverage I would have hoped. But, then again, maybe as President Trump would conclude, we shouldn't be surprised given the orientation of much of the media.

WEBSTER: John, you're the economist here. How much of a boost can this tax reform give to the U.S. economy?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: We've got some problems here. The first thing is --

WEBSTER: Don't say that.

LONSKI: Well, hey, let's face it. We have a low personal savings rat. We have many Americans living paycheck to paycheck.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LONSKI: Who's to say that this cut and middle income tax won't be save (ph) instead of spend. That is one problem.

Another problem is, we have a very low unemployment rate, suggesting we may not have enough idle qualified workers, and so that if we do get an increase in demand we can increase output in kind. We may end up with a tax cut, but sad to say, does more to still price inflation (ph) than to increase real business activity.

WEBSTER: So really, to follow up, John, this is for the corporations. It's a far more positive piece of legislation. Several aspects, one the repatriation, all of those billions, maybe up to a trillion dollars overseas. First question to you, what are they going to do with that money?

LONSKI: Well, let's be careful about that. Yes, there's about $1.4 trillion in cash held overseas by U.S. corporations, but for the most part these are holdings of a relatively small segment of corporate America, principally, we're looking at high-tech companies as well as farmers. So they bring all these cash back, --

WEBSTER: Right.

LONSKI: Are they necessarily going to invest it in new plant and equipment? Perhaps not. I think a lot of this cash ends up going to shareholders, and some of the cash will also be used to finance mergers and acquisitions especially as far as Big Pharma is concerned and of course those large high-tech companies keep on going for these bolt-on acquisition so that they can maintain their rapid growth rate.

WEBSTER: Lanhee, John brings up some interesting points. How confident are you the corporations will indeed be, you know, prompted through these reduced tax rates to actually invest? We already heard from Fedex and Southwest Airlines, both saying they're looking to expand and that is exactly what the Trump administration wanted to hear. How optimistic are you that this tax reform is going to actually create jobs?

CHEN: I'm pretty optimistic. Look, it's not going to be universal. I don't think you're going to find that every sector in every business is going to make the same decisions, but there are clearly some situations here where businesses are going to make decisions to invest and grow in the United States, whether that's with physical plant or with employment. I think it clearly is the case. We are relatively low unemployment now. So maybe we don't have too much far to go there, but certainly businesses are going to make decisions based on the tax code. And the one thing that this corporate tax rate gives them is it gives them some certainty to plan around. That is the most important thing --

WEBSTER: Right.

CHEN: -- for a lot of these job creators, they need certainty and they haven't had it for some time.

WEBSTER: John, I just want to talk about the economy, GDP, I mean we're right around three percent, thereabouts as we look ahead to the next year with these tax cuts in mind, can we get above that? Can we start talking about four percent in your mind?

LONSKI: I think there -- too much of a stretch. But I do see growth between 2.5 and three next year which is pretty darn good compared to our recent history on this front. And in fact, we could have three percent growth annually for the first time, I believe, since 2005 believe it or not.

WEBSTER: Think about that.

LONSKI: So, this has some positive features. Economic growth will probably be faster by a quarter tenth percent each point on average over time, and we would hope that with more business investments spending with some clarity about the future of taxation will reach a higher -- a rate of growth for labor productivity and that's going to be positive for wages in this country.

WEBSTER: A positive, I like that, John. Lanhee, let me end with you. Why is it that the Republicans get this tax reform through, it's going to cut tax, and yet when you look at polls a lot of Americans don't like it? Is that the Republicans fault for poor messaging?

CHEN: In part it absolutely is. I think that they have not done nearly a good enough job of describing what the benefits will be. Look there are a lot of benefits here, particularly to middle income taxpayers, and you return to that group, because that's the group that you really want to focus on politically. And you think about the doubling of the standard deduction, the lowering of marginal tax rates, potential wage gains from the corporate tax cut. There's a lot of benefits here. Republicans have been hunkered down, it's like they have PTSD from the Obamacare experience. They haven't been able to move forward and argue why this tax reform is good policy. But it is. And I think we're going to see the payoff next year.

WEBSTER: Yes. Just sell it, baby. Thank you so much Lanhee, and John here in the studio. Thank you both for joining us today. We really appreciate it.

Meanwhile, one of the architects of this tax reform plan, National Economic Council Director, Gary Cohn telling Axios, the stock market rally this year has nothing to do with tax reform. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COHN: I don't think a lot of the tax reform is in the stock market. What I think is in the tax -- what's in the stock market right now is what's going on in the economy. The economy is doing well. Tax cuts are not priced into the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: All right, well, that could explain why the markets actually fell yesterday despite the passage of the highly anticipated bill. But there is a little green today. Essentially flat. The question is, why the ups and downs? It's been mostly up for the markets. Let's bring in Surevest Wealth Management CEO, Rob Luna, and our very own Nicole Petallides down at the New York Stock Exchange. Nicole, let me begin with you. What are you hearing from traders today on why was so flat given, you know, the tax reform bill is in effect, passed and ready to go?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS: We had a couple of great days, Friday and Monday. We're up ove140 points those days. Yesterday was relatively flat. So we didn't give it back. It could be a little bit of a tech when I was talking to one guy who is technician. In fact, he was looking at the eight-day moving average. He said a little back and fall is fine. Some of the tech stocks come under pressure because they won't far, as well possibly with the new tax plan. And we are seeing interest rates on the rise.

Big picture though, people are still feeling really optimistic. I'm not sure that I agree 100 percent from Mr. Gary Cohn about whether or not the market is going up on everything else except for the tax plan. I would say it was everything put together. Fundamentally, great. Economically, great. We've gotten some great economic reports out recently and this also some profit-taking.

So the idea here is that we will grow. This is a growth plan as well for President Trump going forward. So I think the most of the people I speak with are still feeling pretty optimistic.

WEBSTER: Yes, you bring up some very good points Nicole. Rob, let me go to you. Gary Cohn saying, look, the markets haven't even taken into account the tax reform. I think most of the analysts that we've been speaking with believe that, yes, it has, but maybe not fully. What's your thought on that? Do we get another step up now that this is in place?

ROB LUNA, CEO, SUREVEST WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Yes, you know, I have to agree. I might have to think, you know, the run-up that we've had, taxes did played a little bit into that. Let's remember, you know, stock markets are forward-looking.

But, you know, that being said now that we're getting some certainty, projections for the S&P earnings next year are going to have to be ratcheted up. We're looking at 8 to 11 percent projected growth next year. That's going to be ratcheted up to 13 to 17 percent. So that -- coupled with regulatory reform, areas like the banks are going to probably doing well. You have now an increase in capital expenditure expensing.

So there are some positives. I don't think that have been fully baked in that will definitely put a floor into this market next year, but I would be very surprised to see the type of numbers that we put up this year.

WEBSTER: Rob, let me follow-up on that, because we know techs have been doing so much of the heavy lifting. Small number of companies, you know, really, really leading the charge upward. But those companies won't do so from a tax point of view and you mentioned financials. Do you expect to see money coming out of those big tech companies and going elsewhere?

LUNA: Yes, you know, that's a good point. I think the only thing that's really in this for them is the repatriation. If you look like companies like Apple and Google, obviously they have a tremendous amount of money that is overseas, so if that were to come back that could help out a little bit, but it's probably one of the less attractive sectors in our idea. We would be looking at the financials. They're definitely going to benefit from a lower tax rate, also, as I mentioned, regulatory reform and also the industrials. Fedex was getting ready to spend 5.8 billion on capital expenditures now. They did come out and say that they'll increase. They're able to accelerate that depreciation. So financials, industrials in our view are probably the two best sectors that are set up to benefit from this tax cut.

WEBSTER: Very good. Nicole, do they have the 25,000 cap ready to go? Because I remember you're just putting on the 24,000 cap not long ago.

PETALLIDES: I know, right. That was really quick 1000 if they can actually get it sooner than later. They're ready. They look a little different than the last few. So there is a little something special about them so. Not that special. But hey it's 25,000.

Just I will say, a prophetic, Fedex is such a great example of what's been going on --

WEBSTER: Yes.

PETALLIDES: Global economy, seeing a demand, profit expectations that moved -- they move beyond that, and the CEO even saying, look, we can't raise wages until we get a better tax plan and that's exactly what they got. So they're expecting a record holiday season. So things don't seem that bad. They seem good.

WEBSTER: I agree, Rob, very quickly, someone comes to you say, look, I have not jumped into this market rally. I feel terrible. Can they still get in and feel safe?

LUNA: I think they can. You know, I'm predicting positive returns for next year, but I'd be a little bit more selective going into next year. I think we started seeing it this year. It's going to be a little bit more of a stock-pickers market. So maybe stay away from those things and then run up 50 percent - 60 percent like technology. And maybe rotate a little bit more to the portfolio to value stocks like financials right now.

WEBSTER: Very good, great advice. Rob, Nicole, thank you both. Really appreciate it.

LUNA: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Trump Economic Advisor Gary Cohn is saying today that if there is one thing he wishes he could get out of the tax bill it would be eliminating or getting rid of the carried interest loophole. Listen to why he says he couldn't get rid of it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COHN: The reality of this town is that constituency has a very large presence in the House and the Senate. They have, you know, really strong relationships on both sides of the aisle.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: Well, they couldn't get rid of it because the Congress' relationship with private equity and hedge funds. Trish Regan and "The Intelligence Report" have been calling this out since the very beginning. We're on it next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: President Trump's Chief Economic Advisor Gary Cohn saying today there's one thing he wishes he could change in the Republican tax bill it would be eliminating the carried interest loophole, and if you've been watching this show you know Trish has been hammering this loophole over and over again. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: This bill is incomplete and it's penalizing individual high earners, it is penalizing American homeowners, it is still letting the fat cat Wall Street private equity investors get away with paying less tax than say, I don't know, a New York City fireman? So those private equity fat cats get away with paying investment taxes instead of income taxes and that is just wrong!

So why doesn't anyone care? Nobody cared. Nobody bothered and they still don't care. And, you know, this I why, I think, it's important for all of us to be calling this out. We are still left with this hanging around our neck which is the swamp at work, which is the lobbyist at work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: It's those private equity fat cats, to Trish's point. Another person by the way who called out this loophole from the very first day, our very own Charlie Gasparino, says, guess what, they just got away with a big one here. Why on earth --

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS: I can't believe I'm not only one around here.

WEBSTER: Why --

(CROSSTALK)

WEBSTER: -- can't eliminate it?

GASPARINO: We should point out that it wasn't just me and Trish, it's been Claman and Cavuto --

WEBSTER: Sure.

GASPARINO: We've been hammering this from literally day one when Steve Mnuchin essentially biased (ph) the American public where he said Hedge Fund managers will no longer be able to take advantage of this tax loophole known as the carried interest loophole.

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: Guess what, ladies and gentlemen, Hedge Fund managers don't use carried interest. It's private equity which is a whole lot other type of - - that Wall Street --

WEBSTER: Details. Details.

GASPARINO: Hedge Fund guys take other sort of tax -- let's be clear about this tax plan. Kind of break it down.

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: Corporations are getting a huge tax cut.

WEBSTER: 35 to 21.

GASPARINO: Individuals are getting a tiny tax cut.

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: You're going to see $20, $30, maybe in your pocket. I don't know what that is after taxes or whatever. I mean how that dissipates. That's $20, $30 a week, not a lot of money. Hedge Fund managers are going to make out royally. Real estate investment trust, real estate investment are going to make out --

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: -- commercial real estate is going to make out royally. By the way, I can confirm after this is passed that Donald Trump is definitely a billionaire. He's no longer bias to us (ph) anymore. After this passed --

WEBSTER: Well there's the headline --

GASPARINO: He will be a billionaire finally.

WEBSTER: The headline in "The Washington Post" tomorrow, I'm sure.

GASPARINO: Yes. It's going to be, Trump finally a billionaire after he passes his tax bill. Because there's no doubt he's going to be a billionaire after this.

Private equity managers are whooping it up. These are fat cats at Blackstone and Carlyle. And here who's getting screwed. If you're a moderately-to successful man or woman --

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: -- or family --

WEBSTER: OK.

GASPARINO: -- living primarily in New York, New Jersey --

WEBSTER: Good luck.

GASPARINO: -- California and other states, by the way, Texas has very high property taxes. Because they didn't take down the top rate, --

WEBSTER: Right.

GASPARINO: -- and left it basically the same --

WEBSTER: -- come down from 39.6 to 37.

GASPARINO: Thirty seven. OK, so they took it down a little, marginal, and they closed the deductions for housing and state, local taxes.

WEBSTER: -- state and local.

GASPARINO: You, ladies and gentlemen, have just been screwed by the Republican Party.

WEBSTER: And this wasn't the bill that we were expecting --

GASPARINO: No.

WEBSTER: -- when Donald Trump was on the campaign trail.

GASPARINO: No. And what he ran on. And, you know, what else is pretty absurd, is Gary Cohn, Trump's National Economic Advisor --

WEBSTER: He is outraged about the carried interest.

GASPARINO: He is so full of "you know what," and here's why. The White House never made it priority to get rid of carried interest. He is full of it. I'm telling you.

WEBSTER: So he's just making that up?

GASPARINO: -- how you know he's full of it. When Mnuchin first announced their carried interest plan, --

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: -- he started blowing smoke saying, that we're going to get rid of it for Hedge Fund managers. That's how -- they never made it a priority, they kept it the same, getting rid for Hedge Fund managers who don't use it. These guys are double-talking. And here's the thing, I think it's a lot good in this plan --

WEBSTER: Sure.

GASPARINO: -- I mean, taking now the corporate is great.

WEBSTER: Yes. Corporate is great.

GASPARINO: And I have no problem giving fat cats some tax breaks if they create jobs, it's great, --

WEBSTER: Right.

GASPARINO: -- it's great, but don't do it on the backs of other people. If you're going to close some loopholes like state and local tax, close the carried interest deduction.

WEBSTER: Right.

GASPARINO: By the way --

WEBSTER: Keep hammering away.

GASPARINO: And some of these other things are so bad, they screwed so many people and they're going to see this in their tax bill this coming year. Does it go into effect immediately or --

WEBSTER: Yes. You'll start seeing it in February, right? We're going to the New Year, the first paychecks in February. That's when --

GASPARINO: Like I said, your guy in Texas, he may get $20, $30 a week. There is meal I guess somewhere. By the way, I've been to Texas. It's not that cheap.

WEBSTER: No. But they don't have a state income tax, do they?

GASPARINO: No. Listen, I'm all for sticking it to Andrew Cuomo and liberals here, --

WEBSTER: Yes.

GASPARINO: -- just do it in a better way. They just literally screwed people here in New York.

WEBSTER: That's a great way to end it, right there, Charlie Gasparino. Charlie, thank you very much.

GASPARINO: OK.

WEBSTER: Appreciate it.

Members of Congress boarding buses right now on Capitol Hill. They'll be making their way to the White House of course where the President will speak shortly after the GOP passed the most comprehensive tax reform in some 30 years. We'll bring you that live when it happens.

Meanwhile, Democrats losing their minds over the Republican tax plan and poll show the American public doesn't like it much either, but is this a messaging problem, a failure of the mainstream media perhaps to point out that 80 percent of Americans will actually get a tax cut? Or there's something else going on? We've got the Intel next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Well, no doubt it's been a historic week for America. The first major tax overhaul the country has seen in three decade, a generation. Now just about ready to hit President Trump's desk for signature, but the way some on the left responded you think the apocalypse is ready to rain down on us in any moment. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NANCY PELOSI (D), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: This is the worst bill to ever come to the floor of the House. With stiff competition for what some of the things they tried to do. It is disgusting smash-and-grab.

CHARLES SCHUMER (D), SENATOR, NEW YORK: This tax bill will be an anchor around the ankles of every Republican. If they haven't learned it yet, they're going to learn it next November. Republicans will rue the day they passed this bill.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: Rue the day they say. While there are some things in tax bill that definitely need to be cleaned up, how can listening Americans, watching Americans separate all the rhetoric from reality? It's not easy, is it? We have to talk about it, though, Republican Strategist, Boyd Matheson, and Democratic Strategist, Robin Biro. Thank you both for being here.

Robin, let me go to you first because, you know, I hear these expressions to describe this tax reform bill, disgrace, absolute disgrace, disgusting, tax high sham, scam. Is it really that bad, the worst piece of legislation ever to cross Capitol Hill as Nancy Pelosi says?

ROBIN BIRO, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Oh, she has a tendency to exaggerate, you know, Chicken Little, The Sky is Falling I would say. It's not perfect. That's far from perfect. And Mitch McConnell himself knows that they've got to get out and sell this to the American public right now.

But the bottom line is that most all Americans, eight out of 10 will be receiving a tax cut. Now, so I will say that the lower income people are, Mitch McConnell, he said so himself, that they'll be getting about a two percent tax increase. The middle class will be seeing about -- as I understand, about $15 extra per paycheck.

But hey, that might be small, but money is money. So, we'll just have to see how this plays out. But no, I don't think as dramatic as my peers say.

WEBSTER: Thank you for that, Robin. Boyd, let me get to you. And Robin brings up a good point. I mean, eight out of 10 Americans are actually going to see less in tax and yet it seems to me the Republicans have done a really poor job of selling this to the public.

BOYD MATHESON, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Yes. The Republicans have absolutely failed in messaging this thing. There were great opportunities for them to talk about.

Actually, being the party of the little guy and watching out for those, but they -- because they followed the same process, this was so similar to how Obamacare went through, that it's just -- it's bad strategy, it's bad process and bad policy in the end.

And so while -- I do think there's a lot of good things in the bill. I think everybody agrees, every dollar makes a difference for hard-working Americans for sure. But the interesting thing is, Republicans looked at this as a must-pass to get a political victory.

And when you're trying to solve political problems instead of the American people's problem, you usually lose. And if the American people in the end don't buy it, which most still don't, most Americans don't think this is going to be good for them.

This could be a very pyrrhic victory for the GOP in the end. Because if those forgotten Americans feel like, well, yeah, they took care of the fat cats and the big business folks, they will have a problem in 2018.

WEBSTER: Robin, let me ask you this. The Democrats (INAUDIBLE) have said no across the board, is that a gamble? What happens if this tax reform bill actually does wonders for the economies, really, you know, hiring picks up, companies expand, everybody is happy with the fact that the Democrats have all gone against this bill, could that really hurt them in November next year?

BIRO: I've been pondering the same thing exactly. It depends on how effective the GOP actually is at selling this. People will notice the difference in their paychecks come February. So, we'll have to see.

And, you know, it's going to be basically, Trump made a lot of promises on the campaign trail. So, I'm just curious to see if these tax cuts are going to be enough to appease his base. But, you know, it really could actually backfire on Democrats because nobody gt onboard with this.

But like I said, it's just going to -- we're going to have to see. It was death to Obama with Obamacare. We made, you know, 500 amendments to appease the GOP and nobody was really happy with Obamacare in the end and we paid a terrible price for it in the midterms.

That could also happen to Republicans. So, it's sort of anyone's guess right now and I know that this is an unpopular bill right now with Americans, but let's see how chips fall into place come February.

WEBSTER: Boyd, let me finish with you quickly. Does this really now help to bring the party, the GOP together and can it give them momentum as they head into the new year, maybe infrastructure or something else?

MATHESON: Yes. There's a lot of things on the plate and I agree with Robin. This is really going to come down to a messaging strategy, have a messaging strategy that's as strong as your policy strategy and do you make that work for hard-working Americans.

The Democrats have the problem if they're only against things. They missed an opportunity with Senator Rubio and Lee on child tax credit because they all agreed and championed it, but then they voted no in the end.

And so really, it's going to come down who's really going to come to the table for the American people and make it happen.

WEBSTER: We'll find out. Boyd and Robin, thank you both for joining us, really appreciate it. Thank you.

MATHESON: Thanks, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Thank you. And we will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Well, we're about 30 minutes away now from the big ceremony at the White House following the passage of tax reform in Congress. And joining us now, Republican Congressman from Georgia, Doug Collins. Congressman, great to see you.

DOUG COLLINS (R), CONGRESSMAN, GEORGIA: Good to see you as well, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Yes. And congratulations. Listen, here's the problem I have. The latest polls, if you believe polls anymore, but they do show majority of Americans do not support this tax reform bill. How can that be?

COLLINS: Well, I mean, I was just listening to your previous segment. I was sort of appalled at the commentators. We're -- it's not comparing Obamacare and comparing to other things.

This is tax reform plan that was designed to give people more money in their pockets. I mean, if you want to be a Democrat in February and go explain to people why they should have less money in their paycheck, go right ahead, be my guest.

That's going to be your challenge. I think the big thing here is you can have mainstream media, you have people who like government control. Ms. Pelosi, Mr. Schumer, all these -- they enjoy a philosophy that says government is good.

We enjoy a philosophy that said money in people's pockets is better. So, I think this is just the deal. We're going to go out and we're going to sell this. We're going to go out and tell people what this is going to do. You don't have to tell business owners in district, this is good.

I've been getting texts all morning, congratulations. So, we can actually move forward and do things and get a growth rate of three percent instead of the anemic 1.8 percent that Obama administration thought was a good idea.

So, these commentators who want to do political and to say that this was just simply for politics, come to my district. I'll challenge -- you know, if you want to say (INAUDIBLE), come to my district and tell that to the people who are going to get tax relief. That's a lot of hogwash. We're going to continue to fight for the American people.

WEBSTER: Isn't this a big gamble by the Democrats? I mean, it's a universal no across the board if it works out as the Trump administration believes it will that the economy will pick up, corporations will use the extra money to invest and create jobs, that's really going to hurt the Democrats next November isn't it?

COLLINS: Well, you know, look, that's going to be their poor campaigning to do. I think what I want to look at is I say, you know, let's go out there and I would rather be inside with American people.

I want to bet on the American entrepreneurial spirit. I want to bet on the American right now who maybe doesn't have a job, who's going to get a job after this. You're somebody who voted against tax reform. You voted against giving eight out of 10 people a tax break. You voted against letting businesses be able to decide better how they can invest to their money to help their own employees.

If that's the bet you're wanting to make, then you're betting against the American people. I would rather be on side of the American people saying let's unleash the best workforce, the best innovation, the best company had the worst tax plan, let's put them with a good tax plan and see what they can do. I bet on the American people.

WEBSTER: Yes. You know, listen, the sausage-making as they call it is never a pretty thing. But has this finally brought the GOP together do you think, provided some momentum so now we can push through into the New Year and really, you know, start putting this agenda in place?

COLLINS: That is my hope as well. We've got a great victory day and we don't want to downplay that. We're going to celebrate that victory day, but we've got to go right into our funding mechanisms.

We've got to also go into getting our fiscal house in order as we've always said we were and this gives us the growth opportunity to have the revenue, to have an economy that works.

I mean, when you have three or four percent growth, there's a lot of different things that get better, but it gives us the opportunity to focus on our debt in depth and do the things that we needed to do like fund our defense department, fund those men and women who are out there on the front-line every day.

As a member of the military, that is priority we've got to have and we've got to continue to look at that. And so, we're looking forward to the New Year.

WEBSTER: Well listen, you know, all the good feelings will go straight out of the window if we don't get an agreement by Friday on midnight to keep the government running because we need to get another, whatever it is, a continuing resolution to keep the lights on. That's going to happen, right? I can't imagine that the government will shut down right before Christmas.

COLLINS: I don't see that happening as well. And I think the interesting thing here is why don't -- I would love to see the Democrats get onboard with us and say, let's take the politics out of our defense department.

Let's fund our defense department for the next year and tell the Senate that they need to work on the appropriations bills that we sent them already. We're in the House doing our job. We're getting sort of tired of not having a partner on other side of the building that's working through bills.

We want to work together. We're going to find a solution for this, this weekend, but we've got a longer term problem, we need to fix in the beginning of next year and I think you're going to see that.

WEBSTER: I know this is a retrospective question, congressman, but I'm just kind of out of interest, do you wish you'd done tax reform first before tackling Obamacare?

COLLINS: No, I don't. I think what we got in tax reform is an -- we got that fixed. But I think I want to go back. You brought up a great thing retrospectively. I think about people in my community who can't find a doctor.

I got a call just the other day from a guy in one of my counties who cannot get insurance for he's an independent employer. He can't find insurance that he can afford. And even if he could, he was told by the doctors and hospitals in his community, they won't accept it. This is national crisis that President Obama and Ms. Pelosi threw on our laps. We need to fix it.

We don't just band aid it. It's a broken system that has put people out. Some people were helped, I never denied that, the preexisting conditions, those folks who can't find insurance. But we can't ignore the chaos and havoc that Obamacare is still wreaking on the American public.

WEBSTER: All right. We'll have to leave it there. Thank you so much Congressman Doug Collins, Republican from Georgia. Thank you for joining us on this historic day. We really appreciate it.

COLLINS: It's a great day. Thanks for having me.

WEBSTER: Thank you. President Trump, by the way, is expected to speak any minute from now following the passage of tax reform in Congress. We'll bring it to you live.

Plus, ride-sharing company Uber dealt a major blow as the European Union rules it's a transport company, not a tech company, leaving it vulnerable to lots of new E.U. regulations. What does this mean for the company's future? We'll talk about it next

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: (INAUDIBLE) speed on the markets. The Dow hits session lows now. We're up 32 points. When you first started the day all the way back at 9:30 this morning. The markets were up close to 100 points. We thought we're up to the races.

Since that point, maybe it's a bit of profit-taking, maybe selling on the fact after buying on the rumor with the tax reform bill, whatever. We're down 33 points now. But let's be honest, we're still down 24,721, not bad.

As for other stocks, shares Stitch Fix dropping more than 10 percent after reporting its first earnings as a publicly trading company. Earnings and revenue beat analysts' expectations, good, but gross margins fell due to investments in new categories, not so good, but stocks taking a hit.

Federal investigators in the -- another setback by the way, let's move on. We're going to do the (INAUDIBLE) story, but we're going to get to this Uber story. A setback for Uber as a top E.U. court rules that the ride hailing company should be regulated as a taxi company, not a tech company.

Adam Shapiro joins me now with what this means for Uber. We know the Europeans love their regulations, but this is a blow for them.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: To a degree, now, keep in mind, Uber is going to tell you that they are already regulated in the different E.U. countries, but this was a fight that involved taxi drivers in Spain, the Taxi Drivers Union against Uber.

And in this case, the taxi drivers in Spain have won because now the laws of Spain, Barcelona, the taxi drivers are going to apply for the ride-share company. What Uber was saying in court is that, no, no, no, we're not a transportation company per se, we just connect (ph) people through the app.

Well, it's the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled, no, you are a transport service and therefore you are subject to the laws within each different E.U. countries. So, here's what Uber said, we did reach out to them. They sent a statement.

This ruling does not change things in most E.U. countries where we already operate under transportation law. However, millions of Europeans are still prevented from using apps like ours. There are some countries where Uber does not operate in Europe, but they are in, what is it, 600 cities.

WEBSTER: Yes.

SHAPIRO: And they're in 77 countries.

WEBSTER: Right.

SHAPIRO: So a setback, not so much, but they're going to have to now, in Spain, apply to the regulations that Spain is going to --

WEBSTER: Well, what's interesting I think is that a lot about the countries kind of follow the E.U. because E.U. has a rule, the right to be forgotten rule with your personal information.

SHAPIRO: Right.

WEBSTER: Well, other countries started following that. There is a concern that other countries will look at this and start doing the same thing to Uber somewhere else in the world.

And also, what about other gig economy type of businesses? What about Airbnb, could that suddenly be regulated as part of the hotel industry?

SHAPIRO: If the E.U. sees a way to protect -- if the industries within the individual countries in the E.U. can make a successful argument to protect the old order, they will. But that's why we're United States. Creative destruction always wins.

WEBSTER: Right. But to your point, the drivers, especially, you know, the London cabbies, very, very upset with Uber and as you mentioned, Spain, and in France has gotten very quite violent, a lot of protests.

SHAPIRO: Yes. But in Germany, remember that they negotiated a deal to avoid all of this. So, they are complying with the regulations, but it's individual to the countries in which they operate within the E.U.

WEBSTER: So, the bottom line is from Uber is, OK, we lost. But in reality, we're living with these relations anyway.

SHAPIRO: In other countries, yes.

WEBSTER: In other countries. Interesting stuff, Adam, thank you very much. Appreciate it.

Well, as you know, President is expected to speak any minute now following the passage of the tax reform in Congress. Finally, they're gathering on the lawn. We'll bring it to you live. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: We are moments away from President Trump speaking about that historic tax reform that has made it through both the House and the Senate. It is a massive victory for his administration, a much-need one, but there's been many more.

So my question is, why aren't we hearing about them as much? Well, here to discuss Presidential Historian Doug Wead. Doug, before I get into some of the details, have we ever seen a president like Donald Trump?

DOUG WEAD, PRESIDENTIAL HISTORIAN: Never, never, Ashley. I would say that Donald Trump, love him or hate him, has been the most impactful president we've had since Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

I mean, we've got these jobs, 1.7 million jobs this first year, immigration, illegal immigration dropping like a rock, unemployment, lowest in 17 years. Amazing -- take for example energy independence, Jimmy Carter would've cut off his right arm for that.

Presidents have begged for that on and on the list goes, truly remarkable. ISIS has been wiped off the maps of the Middle East. This is a pretty remarkable year.

WEBSTER: And yet, if you listen to the mainstream media, Doug, you don't really get that sense at all. Have you ever seen a president given so much negative coverage?

WEAD: No, and the numbers show that. I saw one 91 percent and another one similar was 90 percent, negative. And if we've known that going in, we would've said this guy is a goner. But there's a dramatic change taking place with YouTube and live streaming and Twitter and he's taking advantage of that technological change and there's resistance in the marketplace.

And you can see the mainstream media is just shrill. They can feel this change of power, they don't like it. They're like a parent whose kid is going out on their own and they don't like it one bit. But Lord Melbourne once said, the problem with the scandal is you never know who gets splashed by mud.

So now, the Russian scandal is backfiring a little bit and involving Democrats, so is the sex scandal with the Lisa Bloom thing and today you had McCabe on Capitol Hill testifying, so obstruction of justice isn't working for them either. So, it's high drama, high drama.

WEBSTER: Never a dull moment, that's for sure. Listen, we know what's been going on here domestically, but how do you think Donald Trump is perceived around the world?

WEAD: Very interesting to me because I travel the world a lot. So, I'll sit in a taxicab in Paris and it's very similar to what we experience here. People won't open up and really tell you what they think unless you do it first. And then, they'll weigh in.

A lot of people around the world had similar instincts that the system is corrupt, that the central bank works for some, not for others, that the environmental regulations are enforced for some companies, not others, not enough competition, not enough room for the little guy.

So, there are some out there, the numbers wouldn't show it that are rooting for and just as there were here in this country.

WEBSTER: And there was some not rooting for within his own party and that certainly came out. Do you think this legislative wind which was much needed as I say on tax reform, can this give him and the administration the momentum they need, you think, to start really pushing forward next year with other items like infrastructure?

WEAD: Yes. This is big. Ashley, you said it correctly. This is big. If you stop and think, it took Ronald Reagan five years to get here. He got his tax cut, but he didn't get tax reform which was his crown jewel of his whole time in office until his fifth year.

So, this has got to show some in the establishment. But remember, they don't call it the establishment for nothing and it's Democrats and Republicans and they're hanging on for dear life to a rigged system that benefits them.

So, they've got to see that the free market really is better. I call it, yell and envy, and that is the corporate guy says maybe that company is cheating better than we are, maybe it's better for us to go free market again.

WEBSTER: I got 30 seconds, Doug. Do you think Donald Trump is getting better at the job, is he learning, is he learning from his mistakes?

WEAD: You know, I wonder about that, Ashley. I think maybe I'm figuring him out a little bit better than I have. He may have been a little more calculative than I gave him credit for. But yes, he's got a lot to brag about this first year, no question about it.

WEBSTER: Certainly, Doug. Doug Wead, fantastic stuff. Presidential Historian Doug, thank you very much.

We are literally moments away now from President Trump who is holding an event with lawmakers for the passage of the tax reform bill.

The President eager to claim his first major legislative victory as what's being billed as a bill passage event. There'll be actually no signing. That will probably come maybe next week sometime, maybe in early January because of all the procedural things that have to happen.

But a time for a huge victory party, if you like, the lawmakers (INAUDIBLE) and they're all on the front lawn and pretty soon the President will be out there to lead the party forward. Liz Claman will take you through it all. Liz.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R7G-FH81-DY0W-40RG-00000-00Trump To Hold Tax Reform Ceremony At White House; Tax Loopholes Debate; Stocks Fell After Tax Vote; Gary Cohn Blames Congress For Carried2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump To Hold Tax Reform Ceremony At White House; Tax Loopholes Debate; Stocks Fell After Tax Vote; Gary Cohn Blames Congress For CarriedLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX ANCHOR: -- hopping into a bus. They make their way to the White House and Ashley Webster will monitor what they say when they do. Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: -- the party bus. Neil, thank you very much.

Breaking right now, President Trump will be speaking in about an hour from now, after securing his first legislative win, tax reform, finally, Republican lawmakers passing the most consequential reform in over 30 years in a generation.

Good afternoon everybody. I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. Welcome everyone to "The Intelligence Report."

And by the way, as Neil said, you are looking live right now of Republican House members getting on buses, (INAUDIBLE) those bus. They're going to head on over to the White House to celebrate this big win with the President and they're getting driven over there in those buses.

Now, which the President, by the way, did with no Democratic support and without losing a single Republican senator, so, will we see more legislative wins next year in 2018? And what's next for the Republican Party? We'll be asking Presidential Historian Doug Wead and Republican Congressman Doug Collins. We'll get their thoughts on that.

"The Wall Street Journal" editorial board which has been critical of the President praising the Republican tax bill saying, "it is the most pro- growth policy since the Reagan reforms of 1991 and 1986," but the board did note that Reagan reforms were better for individuals.

Lanhee, I just want to get you first. I was looking at some of your notes on this. You are we'll see faster growth, better job creation, 80 percent of taxpayers will see tax cuts because of this bill, including many middle income Americans. So in your mind this is a huge plus for the economy?

LANHEE CHEN, HOOVER INSTITUTE RESEARCH FELLOW: I do think it's a huge plus for the economy. I think that it's unfortunate it hasn't been covered more that way. If you look at the impacts on individuals, you've got significant tax relief for many individuals, particularly the middle class. I do think the corporate rate tax cut is hugely important. Immediate expensing is going to move up, a lot of that capital expenditure into 2018 and 2019.

So I think this is a very, very big deal. It's a huge accomplishment. And we haven't seen nearly the kind of coverage I would have hoped. But, then again, maybe as President Trump would conclude, we shouldn't be surprised given the orientation of much of the media.

WEBSTER: John, you're the economist here. How much of a boost can this tax reform give to the U.S. economy?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: We've got some problems here. The first thing is --

WEBSTER: Don't say that.

LONSKI: Well, hey, let's face it. We have a low personal savings rat. We have many Americans living paycheck to paycheck.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LONSKI: Who's to say that this cut and middle income tax won't be save (ph) instead of spend. That is one problem.

Another problem is, we have a very low unemployment rate, suggesting we may not have enough idle qualified workers, and so that if we do get an increase in demand we can increase output in kind. We may end up with a tax cut, but sad to say, does more to still price inflation (ph) than to increase real business activity.

WEBSTER: So really, to follow up, John, this is for the corporations. It's a far more positive piece of legislation. Several aspects, one the repatriation, all of those billions, maybe up to a trillion dollars overseas. First question to you, what are they going to do with that money?

LONSKI: Well, let's be careful about that. Yes, there's about $1.4 trillion in cash held overseas by U.S. corporations, but for the most part these are holdings of a relatively small segment of corporate America, principally, we're looking at high-tech companies as well as farmers. So they bring all these cash back, --

WEBSTER: Right.

LONSKI: Are they necessarily going to invest it in new plant and equipment? Perhaps not. I think a lot of this cash ends up going to shareholders, and some of the cash will also be used to finance mergers and acquisitions especially as far as Big Pharma is concerned and of course those large high-tech companies keep on going for these bolt-on acquisition so that they can maintain their rapid growth rate.

WEBSTER: Lanhee, John brings up some interesting points. How confident are you the corporations will indeed be, you know, prompted through these reduced tax rates to actually invest? How optimistic are you that this tax reform is going to actually create jobs?

CHEN: I'm pretty optimistic. Look, it's not going to be universal. I don't think you're going to find that every sector in every business is going to make the same decisions, but there are clearly some situations here where businesses are going to make decisions to invest and grow in the United States, whether that's with physical plant or with employment. I think it clearly is the case. We are relatively low unemployment now. So maybe we don't have too much far to go there, but certainly businesses are going to make decisions based on the tax code. And the one thing that this corporate tax rate gives them is it gives them some certainty to plan around. That is the most important thing --

WEBSTER: Right.

CHEN: -- for a lot of these job creators, they need certainty and they haven't had it for some time.

WEBSTER: John, I just want to talk about the economy, GDP, I mean we're right around three percent, thereabouts as we look ahead to the next year with these tax cuts in mind, can we get above that? Can we start talking about four percent in your mind?

LONSKI: I think there -- too much of a stretch. But I do see growth between 2.5 and three next year which is pretty darn good compared to our recent history on this front. And in fact, we could have three percent growth annually for the first time, I believe, since 2005 believe it or not.

WEBSTER: Think about that.

LONSKI: So, this has some positive features. Economic growth will probably be faster by a quarter tenth percent each point on average over time, and we would hope that with more business investments spending with some clarity about the future of taxation will reach a higher -- a rate of growth for labor productivity and that's going to be positive for wages in this country.

WEBSTER: A positive, I like that, John. Lanhee, let me end with you. Why is it that the Republicans get this tax reform through, it's going to cut tax, and yet when you look at polls a lot of Americans don't like it? Is that the Republicans fault for poor messaging?

CHEN: In part it absolutely is. I think that they have not done nearly a good enough job of describing what the benefits will be. Look there are a lot of benefits here, particularly to middle income taxpayers, and you return to that group, because that's the group that you really want to focus on politically. And you think about the doubling of the standard deduction, the lowering of marginal tax rates, potential wage gains from the corporate tax cut. There's a lot of benefits here. Republicans have been hunkered down, it's like they have PTSD from the Obamacare experience. They haven't been able to move forward and argue why this tax reform is good policy. But it is. And I think we're going to see the payoff next year.

WEBSTER: Yes. Just sell it, baby. Thank you so much Lanhee, and John here in the studio. Thank you both for joining us today. We really appreciate it.
