urn:contentItem:5RPJ-M5D1-DXH2-608C-00000-00Trump To Host Student Listening Session After Florida Massacre; Alabama Officer Killed, Suspect Found Dead After Standoff; Priceline To Change Its Name To Booking Holdings, Symbol (BKNG); Spotify Job Listings Hint At Possible Smart Speaker2018-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKevin Kelly, Mike Murphy, Ronna McDaniel, Paul ChristopherNEWSFinancial022103cb.231Trump To Host Student Listening Session After Florida Massacre; Alabama Officer Killed, Suspect Found Dead After Standoff; Priceline To Change Its Name To Booking Holdings, Symbol (BKNG); Spotify Job Listings Hint At Possible Smart SpeakerMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Blake Burman, Cheryl Casone, Gerri Willis, Charles Payne

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, February 21st, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. The winning streaks snap, stocks down in their first trading day of the week yesterday with the Dow closing down about 250 points, futures this morning, look like this, we are expecting another nervous, open the Dow Industrials down about 30 points right now.

The S&P 500 also negative but the NASDAQ well off of it the highs is up 10 points rights now. In Europe this morning, mixed performances there as well. Mostly lower, FT-100 now back in negative territory by a fraction. The CAC quarante in a Paris is down a third of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany downtown two-thirds of one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board, China is still closed for lunar New Year, it is the year of the dog. The other majors were up, as you can see, Hong Kong up almost two percent.

Battle over gun control front and center, President Trump set to hold a listening session today with the survivors of school shootings at the White House. The news coming as the President makes a move to ban so-called bump stock devices. Fox Business is taking you live to the event beginning at 4:15 Eastern today when the President holds that listening session. Stay with us for the latest there.

Then there's this, unpatriotic, that's latest wave that House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi is characterizing the tax plan, she is attacking President Trump's historic tax overhaul once again. Yesterday she said it is a grave disservice to the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: If what you're doing is cutting the taxes at the high end and therefore, not being allowed to invest in the future, you're doing a grave disservice to our country.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Unpatriotic.

PELOSI: Unpatriotic. So --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Pelosi set to hold an event of the "consequences of the GOP tax scam" this afternoon. So we will tell you what she says there. It does not appear that that's resonating with America. Tragedy in Alabama meanwhile, a police officer has been killed, the suspect is also dead, following a standoff with the police. The very latest from the scene this morning. Netflix under fire over a new show that tries to get unsuspecting people to commit murder. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The question we're considering is simple, can we be manipulated through social pressure to commit murder?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More on the controversial new series coming up this morning. And then Spotify tunes into hardware. The music streaming service reportedly looking to make its own speaker, the major impact that could have on Apple and Amazon which have speakers. All those stories coming out this morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Rosecliff CEO, managing partner, Mike Murphy and Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly. Great to see you. Great show so far.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRUBTOR: I'm loving this Spotify news. We're going to becoming public later this year, they're doing a direct listing, they're not really doing an IPO process, so we're going to see. So they're on -- they're actually in the forefront of innovation.

(CROSSTALK)

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: -- kind of crowded though.

KELLY: Well, yes. But the problem is they have a bunch of people streaming already and I pay for Spotify premium and so do 90 million other households, right? So, I think the interesting aspect is that we're seeing this morning, I think the markets going to stay flat until we hear from two members of the Federal Reserve, Philadelphia, Minnesota or Minneapolis to see where they think the Fed is going to raise rates.

BARTIROMO: I like what Harper is doing in Philly by the way.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And by the way also, the PMI, purchasing managers index is out today in Europe.

KELLY: Yes. In Europe, it actually came below expectation, it's still an expansion mode, so they've have had a 57 handle, it's below January, so 58, so we'll see where we go from here but it's still expanded.

BARTIROMO: We'll talk about markets coming up and a lot more.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: And the Apple speaker, how red it is. I'll bring that up.

BARTIROMO: You bought it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. It's better than Amazon and Google speaker a lot.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right. We'll talk about that. We are getting to that this morning. But, first, our top story, a solemn day in Washington this morning. President Trump will hold a "listening session" this afternoon with the survivors of the tragic school shooting in Florida. Blake Burman is at White House now, he has the details. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. As this national conversation that is taking place all across the country moves into White House later today about how to keep classrooms safe. President Trump announcing action as it relates to the Las Vegas massacre, you'll remember from October 1st of last year when 58 people were killed, 850 others injured, after more than 1100 rounds were fired into a concert there due to the use of a bump stock. A bump stock allows for a gun to be modified and fired at a rapid succession. Well, now President Trump says, he wants to see regulations on bump stocks that would amount to a ban.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I signed a memorandum directing the Attorney General to propose regulation to ban all devices that turn legal weapons into machine guns. I expect that these critical regulations will be finalized, Jeff, very soon.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: A White House source also tells Fox that President Trump is considering advocating for raising the minimum age of gun ownership, though it's unclear exactly what could be done at the Federal level considering most of this is dealt with at the state level. For now official White House position though is that the President wants to see the national background check system strengthened.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SNADERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I know background checks are something that the President supportive of, making more efficient and looking at better ways to improve that process. And we're going to continue to look at a number of other factors as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Will be at the forefront here at the White House later this afternoon when the President hosts this listening session between students, parents, and teachers. The White House is not yet provided a list of who will be in attendance, so it remains unclear if any students in Parkland will be in attendance. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes, and, of course. All right. Thank you, Blake. We'll be watching that. Blake Burman at the White House. Joining me right now is the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, Ronna McDaniel. Chairwoman, good to see you.

RONNA MCDANIEL, CHAIRWOMAN, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE: Great to be here. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. What are you looking for out of the President today with his listening session? Tell us what you expect to take place.

MCDANIEL: Well, it's a time of national tragedy and during these times we do need to come together and listen, and find ways to prevent these tragedies from happening again and I think the President really is intent to listen to these families. Hearing their stories and saying how can we come together to find solutions so we don't find ourselves in the same situation.

BARTIROMO: Congress of course is out of session this week there in their districts but what do you think comes out of all this? I mean, the President is trying to come up with something, pretty good op-ed in the -- in Journal today about this gun control debate taking front, center again. Do you think -- do you expect anything more from the President other than banning the bump stocks and perhaps looking once again at background checks?

MCDANIEL: Yes. Enhanced background checks. And I think finding out how these tips that came through the local FBI office didn't get elevated and researched, you know, people did the right thing, they saw things on social media they were concerned about this young man, it should have been elevated, so we have to fix this system, and we have to understand the underlying things that are happening with these young boys who are feeling bullied or maybe like social outcasts that they're coming in and wanting to do harm and how do we make sure that guns don't get in their hands?

BARTIROMO: You wonder if this is going to be enough to quiet the people who are upset about guns but also keep the people in his base who want that constitutional right happy, do you think this is enough? Redoing or relooking at background checks and the bump stocks.

MCDANIEL: I think everyone wants to look at whole picture and if you just look at the gun portion of it, you're missing the underlying symptoms that took this individual --

BARTIROMO: Mental health.

MCDANIEL: -- or place where he wanted to break every law, the most important law which is taking human life. So we have to figure out what's going on with these individuals that they're getting missed and background checks, nobody wants guns in their hands.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDANIEL: And that's universal, that's not partisan, we do not want guns in the hands of people who are going to go take human life.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. We'll watch that today, 4:15, Fox Business is taking our audience live there. Then there's this, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi once again out talking about the historic Republican tax overhaul, negatively, now she -- not only is it crumbs but she said it's unpatriotic. Listen to what her comments were yesterday and the immediate backlash that she faced over her own wealth. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PELOSI: If what you're doing is cutting the taxes at the high end, and, therefore, not being allowed to invest in the future, you are doing a grave disservice to our country.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Unpatriotic.

PELOSI: Unpatriotic. So -- most people have to struggle to make ends meet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: How much are you worth, Nancy?

PELOSI: No, we're not talking about that. So, in any event --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: She said we're not talking that when she was asked, how much are your worth. Apparently, she's got -- she's worth $100 million we're told. But you remember what she said initially about the bonuses, about the crumbs. Listen to what she said last month.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PELOSI: In terms of the bonus that Corporate America received versus the crumbs that they are giving to workers to kind of put the schmooze on is so pathetic so pathetic. It's so pathetic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So PelosI's newest comments come after Politico reported major Democratic super PAC issued a memo last week, they had concerns over the Democratic Party's midterm strategy of just resist, resist, resist opposing the President and the Republican tax plan. Your reaction to all of this.

MCDANIEL: Well, it's just crazy to hear Nancy Pelosi say that giving a tax break to the entire country, it was every tax bracket is unpatriotic and then to see 4.2 million people now benefiting from bonuses or wage increases or increased money into their 401(k), you know, she has to root against it because no Democrat voted for it, so she's going to do everything she can to say it's bad but the numbers speak for themselves, our economy is doing well, wages are up, people are feeling better and I'll tell you personally, when I was putting my husband through law school, and I was making $30,000 a year, my boss brought me and he gave me $1,000 bonus, that was our rent, that's our groceries, it was huge for me at that time in my life and my husband. So to hear her say that, I think is insulting to middle-class Americans. I know she's a millionaire from San Francisco but it is not crumbs to the average working family in this country, $1,000,$ 2000, $3,000 means a lot.

BARTIROMO: It absolutely is not crumbs. I have a friend who told me yesterday, my husband wants you to know and he is construction worker, he's got an $80.00 in his paycheck every week and he is happy as can be. I mean, people are feeling it and they're feeling good about it. What does this mean for November do you think? Because I think that there is a debate on what happens with the midterm elections. We just saw another victory on the Democratic side in Kentucky, does that worry you?

MCDANIEL: Well, the Kentucky one is an anomaly because you had a disgraced senator and a lot of issues going on with that one, so --

BARTIROMO: OK. So you put Kentucky aside.

MCDANIEL: Kentucky is an anomaly. Listen, midterms are tough on the party that holds the White House but the RNC has outraised the Democrats significantly, we have 40 times more cash on hand because we know what we're up against. Democrats thought they were going to in the White House in 2016, now they're energized, their abstract and resist message, I do not thing will resonate because we are putting forward a message of vision, of opportunity, of growth and it's helping the average American family. And I think that's going to win every time.

BARTIROMO: I know the Republicans are raising a lot of money, I see the numbers, tens of millions of dollars, so that's great. But on the local level, individual giving money, the Democrats are out raising the Republicans, right? Because Obama put such a good solid online strategy in place that people could just donate $5.00 or $10.00, the Dems are outstripping the Republicans on that though, right?

MCDANIEL: Yes. But it's really important that the national party strong because we do the data, and the ground game that an individual candidate can't do, it's hundreds of millions of dollars. That's why the party structure being strong is so beneficial, identifying most likely Republican voters and turning them out and an -- and an individual candidate just doesn't have bandwidth to do with the national party can do. So that differential between the RNC and the DNC is significant.

BARTIROMO: I think you make a really good point. And I agree, I think that -- come November people are going to want answers in terms of what is your message other than just resist President Trump, but now people are upset about the spending coming out of Republicans, I sat down exclusively last week with Speaker Paul Ryan to get his take over this idea that the Republicans have lost fiscal discipline. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL RYAN, SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: So this was a discretionary spending budget, this wasn't a full macro budget, this is discretionary spending and for us, save the military, one time spending for hurricanes disaster, get some spending cuts that will grow in the out- years, but we do have to go back and focus on entitlement spending.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You've got to focus on entitlement spending otherwise you're talking about trillion-dollar deficits for as long as you can see.

MCDANIEL: Yes. I think long term we have to look at the spending, we have to look at the deficit, obviously was a budget to fund our military, deal with things that we dealt with as a country national issues --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: So you're not worried about?

MCDANIEL: I'm not, I know long-term, we're going to be party that's focused on fiscal discipline and the Democrats aren't. And with the tax cuts we're helping grow our economy, Obama was comfortable with two percent growth every year. We saw two quarter of three percent growth and potentially four percent growth coming up this year, so that's very helpful.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. We're talking about -- we're talking about great economic numbers. Let's talk about your uncle, former Massachusetts Governor, Mitt Romney has accepted President Trump's endorsement in his campaign for the Utah Senate seat. They had an up and down relationship. Mitt Romney wasn't never Trumper at one point. Is he no longer a never Trumper?

MCDANIEL: Mitt Romney is a -- I support our country, I support our President. Let's make sure we're doing good things for the American people. And I think every Republican is never-Schumer, never-Pelosi right now. We do not want to lose majorities in the Senate and the House. We know what that will mean for our country.

BARTIROMO: So what Uncle Mitt's priorities be from your standpoint?

MCDANIEL: It's a Utah-based campaign, and his acknowledgement of the President's endorsement, he was thankful for his support but he said I'm looking for the support of the people of Utah. We're neutral at the RNC but he is going to focus on the people of Utah.

BARTIROMO: Good stuff. Ronna, it's good to see you.

MCDANIEL: Thank you. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Ronna McDaniel there. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another police officer tragically killed in the line of duty. Cheryl Casone with the details now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. A standoff in Mobile, Alabama and it was both the suspect and the police officer dead. It all began when a woman was found dead in the middle of the road and police identified her ex-husband Robert Hollie as a person of interest. When authorities went to his home, Hollie fatally shot Officer Justin Billa. And hours after that standoff, Hollie's body was also found inside that home. Not clear whether he died from a self-inflicted gunshot or the shots that were fired by police.

Well, some wild weather across the country today. The east is going to see record-high temperatures for February, 72 here in New York.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes, baby.

CASONE: All right. It's going to be almost 80 in Pittsburgh, this is wild. Meanwhile, there is a severe storm that's causing flooding in the Midwest. More than five inches of rain has been reported in parts of Indiana over the last 24 hours. 28 states from Oregon remain or under winter weather alert. But, you know, enjoy the weather here in New York.

All right. Well, a candidate for the Texas State House has upset former Star Trek actor William Shatner. Brandi Chambers sent out a campaign newsletter nice featuring this photo of herself with Shatner. Now, remember, Chambers, she paid to take the photo at a comic con event. When the 86-year old actor found out about it, he tweeted at her and said, hey, use the photo misleading suggested endorsement on my part. He then told her to remove it. Chambers did remove it and she has apologized. And then finally this, Netflix unveiling a controversial new British reality show.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And the question we're considering is simple. Can we be manipulated through social pleasure to commit murder?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The show was called The Push. It uses actors and elaborate scenarios to test an unsuspecting contestant who they have no idea they're being filmed. The murder doesn't actually happen of course but apparently the situation is so authentic that contestant believe this is all really happening. Someone is trying to convince him to kill somebody. The show is going to go online next Tuesday. Here shares of Netflix higher in the premarket up more than 1-1/4 percent. They stirred in Britain a couple of years ago already. It's -- you don't -- you don't understand how he didn't under -- he didn't believe that he wasn't being filmed but I digress.

BARTIROMO: I don't think it's right to be playing around with people's minds, Dagen, knowing the issues around Alzheimer's, around autism and the fact that we really don't understand the brain as much as we understand other things to be pushing people around and playing with your brain to get you to commit murder is just outrageous.

MCDOWELL: Not something I would ever watch. And I think that it might show a little bit of desperation on Netflix's part in the grab for content that they would pay for this quite frankly, we will see if people watch it.

KELLY: And with kids being --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: With kids, exactly.

KELLY: It's exactly what we don't need. I get it free country and you can put what you want out but, I mean, you have to have some sort of standards, I think.

BARTIROMO: I agree. All right. We'll take a break. When we come back. A judge rejects AT&T and its t request to see the White House communication records about the Time Warner deal. Department of Justice says no. The fight over the megamerger next. And then Wal-Mart's Web site stumbles, why the retail giant struggled with online sales during the holiday season and why the stock fell out of bed yesterday 10 percent. It is bouncing this morning. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We want to bring this breaking news right now, U.S. Christian Evangelist and former counselor to the president's Billy Graham has died. He was 99 years old. Again, the former counselor to president, Billy Graham dead at the age of 99 this morning.

MCDOWELL: Yes. One of the greatest preachers in American history quite frankly. And certainly over the last century. A great spiritual leader for those who are famous just everyday folks, like my whole family quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Lived a long life, 99 years old, Billy Graham, condolences. We want to turn to the megamerger fight, a judge has blocked AT&T's request to see internal White House communications over the merger with Time Warner. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning with details there, looking at a mixed opening this morning. Gerri, good morning to you.

GERRI WILLIS, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, you're right, Maria. So, U.S. district court judge yesterday denying AT&T's request that the Justice Department identify communications between the White House , the Justice Department antitrust division and A.G. Jeff Sessions over this at AT&T merger which was propose with Time Warner but would have been an $85-billion merger. Judge said no way, they wanted logs cataloging this communication, big setback for AT&T , they had claimed that were receiving selective enforcement of antitrust laws and that, you know, implying here that -- or saying out right of Trump's hatred of CNN was behind the rejection of that merger. T shares were down about one percent to say.

Also, you should know AT&T mobile 5G network is going to be rolled out by the end of the year. And they're starting with three cities, Dallas, Atlanta and Waco, where is New York, where is L.A., well, it's coming in the next tranche to -- or nine more cities will be announced as well.

And I want to talk a little bit about Wal-Mart here, you know, that stock up dramatically about 10 percent yesterday. And now, the shares up a little bit this morning but people still concerned about this online sales growth reducing in the fourth quarter down to 23 percent from 50 percent in that third quarter. Now we got Stifel, Raymond James, and Chelsea advisor all cutting price targets on Wal-Mart. So we could see that play out this morning as we get under way. But as you say, mixed opening and I just have to say before you move on from Billy Graham, wow, it's from Charlotte, North Carolina, that is a very big name to pass. Our condolences to the Graham family.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. 99 years old, Gerri.

WILLIS: I know, I know.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Gerri Willis on the floor of The New York Stock Exchange. We have this breaking news as well, Broadcom adjusting its offer for Qualcomm to $79.00 a share. The company also says that other terms of the proposed merger remain unchanged, there is the stock this morning, they have been pushing back, they don't want to do this deal. Mike Murphy, what are your thoughts?

MURPHY: Yes. So, Kevin and I have been talking about this a lot. I think Broadcom had to do this because they drew a line in the sand for Qualcomm. They said, if you can't go above 110 for your purchase of NXPI. They did yesterday Qualcomm announced that they were going to pay up to 127. So Broadcom --

BARTIROMO: Twenty-four billion.

MURPHY: Broadcom had to respond that I think, but ultimately I believe Qualcomm will get acquired because if you're on the board of Qualcomm right now and I'm a big shareholder and you tell me the stock is 62, we have an 82, well, now $79.00 offer on the table, I'm rejecting it. You better have a plan to tell me why you're going to get me better than 79 quickly. So I think ultimately ISS, Institutional Shareholder Services is recommending for a Broadcom's people, for the board we purchased Qualcomm yesterday and I think we'll be buying more of it. So I think ultimately it gets acquired by Broadcom.

BARTIROMO: So and you think they get acquired at 79?

MURPHY: Or higher.

KELLY: Well, yes. And in this press release, I'm looking at right now and says basically if the NXPI deal doesn't go through they will adjust back and give the $3.00 back to make it $82.00 a share. But what's important to note here is that this has been a line in the sand. We don't know the regulatory pressures and hurdles that will be met. That's one of the reason why Qualcomm said listen, we're rejecting this offer because you haven't addressed those concerns. So as a board director, you're saying, listen, I'm not going to lead us into fight and try to get us to $79.00 or $82.00 a share if there's going to be regulatory hurdles and this could drag out longer and longer and longer than we anticipated diminishing shareholder value. So this is going to be interesting to see it play out, there's been a lot of consolidation in the chip space, we don't know how regulators would react to this and this is why Qualcomm share up, board of directors are being very prudent about this. Now Qualcomm also has a giant fight with Apple happening right now over royalty payments. So, there is a lot going on when it comes to --

(CROSSTALK)

MURPHY: And then $8 billion breakup fee. So if the deal doesn't go through, Broadcom has to hand Qualcomm $8 billion.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Yes. Broadcom has the financing, as you had -- as you had mentioned before. So the financing is already in place. And ready to happen, this is a cash-and-stock deal.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Looks like Broadcom is not going away, any time soon, by the way. We'll take a break. As we take break, take a look at futures this morning, big sell-off yesterday, in the first trading day of the week ending a six-day winning streak. This morning, futures are well off of the lows, we are now looking at a possible higher opening for the broader averages. Plus, a rare opportunity for Scary Movie fans, how you can sleep over at the original Friday the 13th campground site. It's been closed to the public. I'm going to tell you how to get in there. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. It is Wednesday, February 21st. Your top stories right now 8:32 on the East Coast. We are an hour away from the opening bell on Wall Street this morning. Futures have completely reversed course. We're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages today after the markets came all the way back from a sell-off earlier. We had been down about 50 points. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve minutes, due out this afternoon, about 2:00 p.m. Eastern. We are expecting the Central Bank's take on inflation as well as any suggestions about the next interest rate increase. People are expecting that come March at the Fed next meeting.

A sell-off yesterday was pretty sharp and severe. The Dow and the S&P 500 snapped a 6-day winning streak with a decline on the Dow of 254 points, one percent lower. The NASDAQ and the S&P 500 also weaker, S&P down 16 points, NASDAQ down five points, yesterday. We're looking at a bounce this morning now. In Europe, stocks are edging lower, FT-100 is up, up a quarter of a percent actually. But the CAC Quarante in Paris is down a quarter of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany off of the lows, down one-half of one percent. In Asia Overnight, green across the board. China remaining closed for the Lunar New Year, the Year of the Dog. Nikkei Average was up a quarter of a percent. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong up almost two percent.

Breaking news this morning, U.S. Christian evangelist and former counselor to the President Billy Graham has died. He was 99 years old. Just that news coming in just half an hour ago.

Meanwhile, new clues in the hunt for Amazon's second headquarters. How Web traffic could be giving away one of the biggest secrets in business. We'll tell you where the suggestions are now for Amazon's second headquarters. Then 3M facing a massive fine. The company paying up nearly $1 billion over pollution claims. Plus, Spotify tuning into hardware. The music- streaming service reportedly looking to make its own speaker, the major impact it could have on Apple and Amazon. All that coming up.

But first, this breaking news right now, a situation is developing in Washington, D.C., right now. We want to bring it to you right away, the Secret Service says that agents and officers are responding to a suspicious vehicle near the White House. The officials have evacuated the new executive offices, traffic in the area has been closed. We are watching the situation, as new information is still coming in. The Secret Service is investigating the suspicious vehicle near the White House. As soon as we know more, we will bring it to you. Right now, all traffic closed, in and around the White House.

Switching gears right now, the Federal Reserve Minutes are due out this afternoon at 2:15 Eastern. Investors are waiting for any signs on the Fed's next move, in particular, raising interest rates. Futures are off of the lows this morning. Joining us right now is the head global market strategist with Wells Fargo Investment Institute, Paul Christopher. Paul, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

PAUL CHRISTOPHER, HEAD GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE: Good morning. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So, you're calling what we've been seeing a technically-driven market correction. Explain.

CHRISTOPHER: Yes, that's right. So, the fundamentals, still look pretty good. The economy is not only solid but broadening. We see good stimulus on the way from tax and the potential to increase productivity which would even drive further economic growth down the road. That said, inflation needs to come up a little bit in order to match where the economy is. And investors are trying to figure out exactly how much inflation that will be. And so, it's a -- it's a sort of a sentiment-driven correction right now. And where -- when markets get down to certain levels, then people will buy. When with they get up to certain levels, there are some who are inclined to sell there, and so, that level-driven selling is what we mean by technicals, the fundamentals are still good.

BARTIROMO: So, is that all -- yes. Is that all it is right now, just technical selling, Mike Murphy? I mean, volatility is here to stay, you said, right?

MURPHY: Yes. So, it could be, but I think the question I would have is really about program trading or computing trading because those drops that we saw in the market a few weeks ago, although I believe the market is -- has more upside from here, but when the computers are the algorithms all started selling at once and we were dropping hundreds of points in what seemed like minutes, that was reminiscent of the flash crash to me. And I hope that the market realizes how much of the selling -- or how much of the volume on a daily basis is coming from those machines. So, that we're in position to have some sort of circuit breakers if needed.

BARTIROMO: You agree with that, Paul?

CHRISTOPHER: Yes, certainly. When you -- when you get the selling reaching a certain point, then the machines will come on in a very noticeable way. They may be operating on a day like yesterday when the selling was there but not extreme, but in order to get to that level, you first have to have other problems, people who are taking profits, short volatility traders, people who are complacent about volatility and bought products that bet on no volatility into the future. Those people, they took their losses first, then you saw profit-taking, and when you finally get down to levels that are low enough, then the algorithms kick in and again, in that noticeable way, and you see those sharper declines like we saw on February the 5th. That's not typical but, yes, that can happen if you get them down to that level of uncertainty in the market.

KELLY: Paul, when it comes down to technical, I think one of the technical that people were looking at where it's actually the multiples on the market, they weren't -- they weren't comfortable with the 20 P.E. on the market given they don't know how the tax cuts are going to roll through in the next quarter, and the quarter after that. And so, then we saw it come down to around 16.6. Where do you see the market ending this year? What's an appropriate market multiple that investors should be paying right now?

CHRISTOPHER: Well, there's that -- there's that historical median that you mentioned, around 16.7. But we think that by the end of the year, the investors will be willing once again to pay a little bit more for stocks, and it gets back to what I said at the outset about the tax reform bill -- the tax reform law now, giving in companies an incentive to add equipment which should improve efficiencies of workers, raise wages, and earnings going forward. We think the earnings part of that virtuous cycle of improvement will drive investors to pay a little bit more than that, historical median. We're looking for something closer to 8. -- 18.9 for the S&P by year-end.

BARTIROMO: That's a big number, 18.9 percent earnings growth, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Right. What if bonds wind up in a bear market? Can -- I think that that's the biggest concern. And in terms of your fixed income allocation, if you want a haven, if you want some ballast, where do you put your money? Because a lot people could be staring at capital losses even in Treasuries depending on the maturities that they own.

CHRISTOPHER: Yes, it's a good point. You put your finger right on the main risk. If the market -- if the stock market and the bond market come to believe that inflation is really going to rise by a lot more than just slightly over two percent, coming up to a more normal level, then the bonds will rise, the Fed will have to hike more, and both of those will be damaging to the stock market, not to mention the damaging impact of inflation on future discounting of earnings. So, yes, that would be the main risk to the market.

In that case, we would have to pull back on our stock view and really expect it to go elsewhere, possibly overseas, and possibly into corporates high-quality bonds, they would pull back less, we think, than the lower- quality bonds, so that would be the strategy in that particular case. But I want to emphasize that is not our base case. We are expecting inflation at a moderate level and we think interest rates have probably finished most of their move higher for this year.

BARTIROMO: So, what areas would you put new money to work here then?

CHRISTOPHER: Well, we still -- again, we still like that economic outlook, that positive outlook that virtual cycle of efficiencies and generating more earnings, so we would be putting more money into those sectors that would do the best under conditions of improving economic growth. Consider industrials, consumer discretionary, we also like financials as the yield curve have steepened a bit and economic growth is better. And as valuation play, we have like health care, although that one is getting a little bit richer going forward. The ones we would stay away from would be the interest rates sensitive sectors like utilities and consumer staples. We would also stay away from energy, because we think oil prices have probably gone a little bit too high, need to consolidate back lower.

KELLY: What about -- what about tech? I mean, that was one name that you -- or one sector that you completely left out but it's not interest-rate sensitive because we look at all these companies, they have net cash on their balance sheet. Their enterprise value is worth less than their market cap. They're doing buybacks, they can do strategic M&A. It was the leader last year. What is your view on tech going forward because we see it up in the premarket?

CHRISTOPHER: Yes, we like -- we like the -- we like the tech. Thank you for bringing that up. We like the tech sector as a market way here, mainly because we like the fundamentals, but think that the valuations are in the middle of a range and we don't want to play that game of paying up for tech stocks and then seeing a sharp correction in those later on. So, market weight on tech and take advantage of the opportunities in the industrials, in the consumer discretionary, the growth-sensitive sectors.

MURPHY: Paul, it's Mike Murphy. On days like yesterday, you have a -- you see a big sell-off in the Dow fueled by Wal-Mart, but when you look at the NASDAQ, the big tech names, and we're basically flat on the day or down a fraction. So, I think that's really where people are still looking for growth and, yes, there's big multiples there, but I think that's where you're really seeing technology play a key and how it's changing our lives, so you've really seen the growth there. So, I think that theme will play out for the rest of the year. So, I think investors could probable even look to be more aggressive in tech as that winning trade looks to continue.

CHRISTOPHER: Yes, we don't disagree with the long-term story but we wonder a little bit about whether there's been too much extrapolation about how quickly, how much, and how soon tech will invade even further our lives, and that's again why we like the fundamentals, but we're happy to have our clients be market weight right now. Take advantage but not be too exposed. We have higher conviction on the cyclicals.

BARTIROMO: So, are you saying, Paul, nothing has changed? You're still bullish on this market, you don't see a lot of things that have changed?

CHRISTOPHER: Yeah, you know, what's really changed, Maria, is the perception that we can just keep grinding higher in a straight line. And we said this in our December report, the outlook for 2018, that we thought the market would make new highs this year. We still believe that will happen even after January. But it will be alongside of this, figuring out how much inflation is going to increase, how much interest rates will rise, and how much the Fed will hike, and that will create, we think, occasional pockets of uncertainty and pullbacks in the market. It's not going to be a straight line, it's going to be a little bit bumpier this year. It's going to offer investors opportunities we think to buy in and put more cash to work.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. We'll be watching, Paul. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHRISTOPHER: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Paul Chritopher of Wells Fargo there. Breaking news, Priceline has just announced it is changing its name to Booking Holdings Incorporated. It's going to change the ticker symbol as well to BKNG, trading under the new name beginning February 27th. That's just out. Coming up, Spotify singing a new tune. The company's reported strategy to compete against Apple's HomePod and Amazon's Alexa, that's next. And not for the faint of heart, how Friday the 13th fans can now stay at the original campgrounds featured in the first movie. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The world is mourning the death of evangelist Billy Graham this morning. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl?

CASONE: That's right, Maria. As we told you just a few minutes ago, influential evangelist, the Reverend Billy Graham has died. Graham was a counselor to presidents, from Harry Truman to Barack Obama. He preached at more than 200 million people during his life and was a key figure in reviving the evangelical movement in this country. Fox News has learned that Graham died from natural causes at his home in North Carolina where he had retired to in 2005. His son, Franklin, now leads his congregation. And Franklin actually spoke at Donald Trump's inauguration last year. The Reverend Billy Graham dead at the age of 99.

Well, 3M has settled the largest environment lawsuit in Minnesota's history. The state accusing the giant consumer products company of contaminating groundwater by disposing PFCs for decadse. 3M is going to pay $850 million, but that's a fraction of the 5 billion that the state was asking for. The company settled without admitting it caused a public health issue. They still faced, though, at least two dozen similar lawsuits around the company. Shares of 3M are up nearly 30 percent over the past year.

Well, you don't see this every day. Queen Elizabeth II making a surprise appearance at London Fashion Week. The 91-year-old monarch watched Richard Quinn show and sat in front row of course with Vogue's Editor-in-Chief Anna Wintour. She made quite the impression and she's even got Anna Wintour smiling. That's a big thing. All right. Queen Elizabeth making a surprised appearance there.

Well, the perfect place for an overnight stay as long as you don't believe that Jason is still out there, could be --

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Never have opened this place again. There's been too much trouble here. Did you know that a young boy drowned the year before those two others were killed?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: That place is the campsite from the "Friday the 13th" movies. It's up for auction if you want to have an overnight stay. This is Camp No-Be-Bo-Sco which is usually a Boy Scout camp and it's always closed to visitors, but they're going to open it up for business. Fans of the slasher film series can bet on the VIP package until February 27th. Special guest Adrienne King, who plays the lone survivor of the movie from, yes, 1980 -- will attend tours of the campsite this year. So, yes, if you want to be scared, yes, go for it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I don't -- I don't -- well --

CASONE: But good luck with that. Somebody have fun.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl.

KELLY: Yes, I don't think I -- yes, I wouldn't stay on that camp ground, but why is everyone surprised the Queen was actually at Fashion Week. She's got a royal wedding coming up. She needs to get a nice dress. I mean --

BARTIROMO: I think she looked better than Anna Wintour.

KELLY: Yes, she did.

BARTIROMO: Good outfit.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And a soul, too, right, compared to Anna Wintour. Maybe you could have some respect to the Queen and take your sunglasses off.

KELLY: I was going to say that, why was she wearing sunglasses.

BARTIROMO: She always does.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's her shtick.

MCDOWELL: Yes, maybe you could check your shtick at the door. (INAUDIBLE) next to the --

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Check your shtick at the door.

MCDOWELL: Head of a royal house.

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to take a break. When we come back, we're going to hear about Dagen's smart speaker, OK? The smart speaker battle is heating up, why Spotify could reportedly take on Apple's HomePod and Amazon's Alexa. It's going to be competitive. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Here comes Spotify. Will Spotify jump from the stream into the growing sea of smart speakers? The online music giant hiring for "connected hardware", the job listings sparking speculation that the company wants in on the business, wants to take on the likes of Amazon Echo and Apple's new HomePod. So, is there a space, Kevin, for a Spotify in the smart -- you said -- you said earlier it's getting a crowded market.

KELLY: Yes, I don't think it's getting a crowded market. There's estimates -- there's going to be over 800 million virtual assistants in use by the year 2020. 43 percent of all voice-activated computing happens in the home; another 36 percent is actually in the car, or it's on cell phones. So, this is a big addressable market. Spotify has -- if you look last June, they said they have 140 million active users worldwide. They recently just did an equity swap with Tencent which is the big technology company over in China. So, I think this is a play for overseas dominance in the Chinese markets where they can address a lot of users who want their home virtual assistants.

BARTIROMO: Now, you have the Apple speaker, right, Dagen, you love it.

MCDOWELL: The quality of it, I would argue that they seem to be -- it's a loss leader. They seem to be selling it at a price that's less than what they're actually paid to develop it and build it because it's -- the sound quality is superior. I would argue at this point, Spotify is being reactive not proactive in terms of coming out with a speaker, because given their user base, they have to provide them with something in order to avoid losing those customers to an Apple at this point or even an Amazon.

KELLY: They're doing very well on the streaming side, right? They've overtaken here in the U.S. more subscribers for their music services. So, yes, they have to be reactive especially to the big behemoth which has an automatically built in user base. So, they need to do something like this.

MURPHY: One thing that shocked me is we just got a few of the Amazon Echos in our house, was how superior the voice controls were for Alexa versus Siri, so I don't -- can't speak to the speaker necessarily, but I think running a venture capital fund, one thing we look for is voice controls and how that's going to be a big part of the future where in everything -- you used to say everything you need will be at the touch of a button, well, now it's actually at the sound of your voice. So, that I think is the big differentiator here, and I wonder about does Spotify moving into this market reminds me a little bit of Snapchat moving into the Spectacles market -- moving into hardware.

BARTIROMO: Too late.

MURPHY: It didn't work out so well.

KELLY: Well, yes, I think there's a little bit of a difference. They were trying to be a leader in that. And if we go back to -- when you're talking about Siri, I mean, think about how Apple was the first that brought out a voice assistant, it was Siri. Now, they're lagging behind Amazon which came out with the Echo that put Alexa in our homes. So, Apple is actually trying to actually react. And I think they're the biggest loser in this situation because they're taking on everybody from all sides, and everyone else is going to be taking market share from Apple. That needs to change.

MCDOWELL: But the speaker quality is good enough that they're giving them all a run for their money.

BARTIROMO: We've got to get to this story before we go because Amazon -- there's a question if the employees accidentally revealed the location of the company's (INAUDIBLE) second headquarters. So, the Web site Arlington now noticed a lot of Web traffic from an internal section of Amazon dedicated to the search for a second headquarters. Arlington County is in the D.C. Metro area which was one of the cities on the tech titan list of 20 finalists. Now, people are saying, because there was so much traffic around this, is Amazon going to Virginia? Is -- are they going near Washington? I think they are because Jeff -- because Jeff Bezos bought like the most expensive house in Washington.

MURPHY: It's on the short list. I mean, to be clear, he could buy the most expensive house anywhere, I guess.

BARTIROMO: You're right. Why did buy Washington?

MURPHY: But it makes -- it makes sense, I think, for the Washington Post, but you have enough space there so they can move all the employees they need --

MCDOWELL: There's no space left in Virginia. Go somewhere else.

BARTIROMO: Oh, we'll be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Great show, everybody.

MURPHY: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Rock on, Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for joining us, everybody. Let's go to "VARNEY & COMPANY" right now. Charles Payne in for Stu this morning. Charles, take it away.

urn:contentItem:600T-R761-F021-6562-00000-00Trump to issue SHOCK executive order on social media in Twitter row;DONALD TRUMP has said he will be issuing an executive order on social media firms on Thursday.2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump to issue SHOCK executive order on social media in Twitter rowDONALD TRUMP has said he will be issuing an executive order on social media firms on Thursday.Dylan Donnelly

The US President has been embroiled in a feud with social media platform Twitter as they have introduced fact checking on a tweet of Trump's about mail-in ballots. It is the first time that Twitter introduced a fact check on the platform.

Earlier on Wednesday, Trump tweeted that social media firms are attempting to censor right wing viewpoints in an attempt to rig the November 3 election.

Trump tweeted: "Big Tech is doing everything in their very considerable power to CENSOR in advance of the 2020 Election.

"If that happens, we no longer have our freedom.

"I will never let it happen!

READ MORE: Donald Trump threatens to SHUT DOWN website over fact row

In the same tweet, he claimed that action will be taken soon.

He continued: "They tried hard in 2016, and lost.

"Now they are going absolutely crazy."

He concluded his tweet with "Stay tuned!"

DON'T MISS

FTSE 100 LIVE: Travel stocks SOAR after holiday boost [LIVE]BBC presenter calls Dominic Cummings 'a d*ck' live on air [INSIGHT]Boris told to impose £444 fine for THIS disgusting coronavirus habit [POLL]

Earlier the same day, Trump tweeted: "Republicans feel that Social Media Platforms totally silence conservatives voices.

"We will strongly regulate, or close them down, before we can ever allow this to happen.

"We saw what they attempted to do, and failed, in 2016.

"We can't let a more sophisticated version of that happen again.

"Just like we can't let large scale Mail-In Ballots take root in our Country.

"It would be a free for all on cheating, forgery and the theft of Ballots.

"Whoever cheated the most would win.

"Likewise, Social Media, clean up your act, now!"

Related articles

President Trump's feud with Twitter in particular had recently taken a giant turn, with Twitter introducing fact checking onto the president tweets.

He had tweeted, without providing evidence: "There is no way that Mail-In Ballots will be anything less than substantially fraudulent."

Twitter added a warning label to the post and linked to a page that described the claims as "unsubstantiated".

It started with Trump posting a conspiracy theory that Lori Klausutis was murdered in 2001 by her boss, MSNBC host Joe Scarborough.

Twitter has refused to delete tweets by US President Donald Trump after a widower publicly implored the company to remove "horrifying lies" about his wife's death, amplified by Mr Trump.

Twitter's chief executive Jack Dorsey responded to criticism of the platform's fact-checking policies in a series of posts, saying: "We'll continue to point out incorrect or disputed information about elections globally."

Twitter has tightened its policies in recent years as it faced criticism that its hands-off approach was helping fake accounts and misinformation to thrive.

In an interview with Fox News on Wednesday, airing on Thursday, Facebook's chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said censoring a social media platform would not be the "right reflex" for a government concerned about censorship.

Shares in both Twitter and Facebook fell in Wednesday's trading session in New York.

urn:contentItem:5WCB-2ND1-F03R-N18W-00000-00Trump told the US stock market exactly what it wanted to hear. Now it's headed for its best day in 2 weeks.2019-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump told the US stock market exactly what it wanted to hear. Now it's headed for its best day in 2 weeks.Rebecca Ungarino

Jun 18, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) REUTERS/Thomas Peter Stocks[1] in the US soared Tuesday, extending earlier gains after President Donald Trump said[2] he and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet later this month at the G20 summit. Trump said that the two sides will engage in discussions leading up to an "extended" conversation between Xi and him during G20. Investors hope a resolution to the ongoing trade war will emerge from the leaders' meeting. Trade tensions between the two global powerhouses have clouded the stock market for months as investors wonder when a deal will be reached. Visit Markets Insider's homepage for more stories[3].President Trump handed stateside stock investors a gift on Tuesday.

"Had a very good telephone conversation with President Xi of China," he wrote on Twitter[4]. "We will be having an extended meeting next week at the G-20 in Japan. Our respective teams will begin talks prior to our meeting." Equity markets in the US soared on that announcement, extending earlier overnight gains[5], as traders interpreted it as removing some worry that's hung over markets for months. The S...00[6] and Dow Jones Industrial Average[7] both jumped by more than 1%, with the S...ow within 1% of its May 1 record high. The Dow rose nearly 400 points. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq Composite[8] climbed almost 2% at its peak. All three major indices were on pace for their best respective sessions since June 4. A bonus just for you:Click here to claim 30 days of access to Business Insider PRIME[9] Trade tensions,big-tech regulation[10] looming in the US, and a slowing global economy have all weighed on equities in recent months. With trade talks appearing to be on the table, at least for now, stocks are finding some reprieve. Elsewhere, traders do not expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates at a two-day meeting ending Wednesday, though the market is anticipating a rate cut in July. Goldman Sachs strategists place the likelihood of a rate cut at the July Federal Open Market Committee meeting at 90%. "With current dovish Fed pricing, potential policy disappointments increase the risk of rate shocks, especially given the strong equity performance this month, which was at least in part due to expectations for easier monetary policy," the firm's strategists wrote Monday in a client note. West Texas Intermediate[11] crude oil, battered since April and pushed into a bear market amid global growth and trade tensions, jumped by nearly 4%. Several trade-sensitive US-listed stocks like Boeing[12] and Micron[13] jumped by nearly 4% and 6%, respectively.The broader semi space jumped along with it; the chip-tracking VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF[14] jumped 4%. urn:contentItem:5WJ7-PHN1-DXFJ-5293-00000-00Trump to meet with big tech as he blasts social media platforms2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:24ZLexisNexisTrump to meet with big tech as he blasts social media platformsShabtai Gold in WashingtonWashington (dpa) -

US President Donald Trump will host a meeting of major technology companies at the White House in the coming weeks, he said Thursday as he bashed social media platforms for having an alleged bias against conservatives.

Trump announced the meeting - details of which were unclear - at a social media summit in Washington, attended by a number of prominent conservative and right wing activists, and also vowed to explore regulatory steps to "protect free speech."

Platforms like Twitter and Facebook have strongly denied they have a political bias.

"Big tech must not censor the voices of the American people," Trump said.

The president used the speech to hail his own skills on social media, but also complained bitterly that he was allegedly being censored on Twitter, his preferred platform.

"I used to watch it. It would be like a rocket ship when I put out a beauty," Trump said about his tweets, alleging that he was now struggling to accumulate new followers at the same pace he once did and that his retweet count was sporadic.

The president also defended his spelling errors on Twitter and accused the media of blowing the issue out of proportion. "I am actually a very good speller but the fingers aren't as good as the brain," he said.

The president repeatedly blasted the media, accusing outlets of being "fake news," a term he says he may have invented, and being "dishonest" and "crooked." He said conservatives online have managed to work around the "gatekeepers" in the mainstream media.

"You communicate directly with our citizens without having to go through the fake news people," Trump said.

Adding to his attack on the media, the president said it was "very dangerous speech" when journalists "see something good and then you purposely write bad." He said: "That's not free speech."

Freedom of speech and the press is protected in the US constitution.

His speech also touched on several of his recurring themes, including blasting socialism and claiming that if his opponents on the left are elected in 2020, the US would "head in the direction of Venezuela."



Editorial contactsEditing by: Peter Godfrey, +61 2 9322 8064, <international@dpa.com;

Trump announced the meeting - details of which were unclear - at a social media summit in Washington, attended by a number of prominent conservative and right wing activists, and also vowed to explore regulatory steps to "protect free speech."

Platforms like Twitter and Facebook have strongly denied they have a political bias.

"Big tech must not censor the voices of the American people," Trump said.

The president used the speech to hail his own skills on social media, but also complained bitterly that he was allegedly being censored on Twitter, his preferred platform.

"I used to watch it. It would be like a rocket ship when I put out a beauty," Trump said about his tweets, alleging that he was now struggling to accumulate new followers at the same pace he once did and that his retweet count was sporadic.

The president repeatedly blasted the media, accusing outlets of being "fake news," a term he says he may have invented, and being "dishonest" and "crooked." He said conservatives online have managed to work around the "gatekeepers" in the mainstream media.

"You communicate directly with our citizens without having to go through the fake news people," Trump said.

His speech also touched on several of his recurring themes, including blasting socialism and claiming that if his opponents on the left are elected in 2020, the US would "head in the direction of Venezuela."
